Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
II. PLAYSTERERS. The Creation, to the fifth day. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor

[Scene, The New World.] Deus. In altissimis habito, in the heghest heuyn my hame haue I, Eterne mentis & ego, withoutyn ende ay lastandly. Sen I haue wroght Ã¾ire worldys wyde, heuen and ayre and erthe also, My hegh godhede I will noght hyde, all yf sume foles be fallyn me fro. When Ã¾ai assent with syn of pride, vp for to trine my trone vnto, In heuen Ã¾ai myght no le[n]gger byde, but wyghtly went to wone in wo; And sen Ã¾ai wrange haue wroght, my likes to lat Ã¾am go, To suffir sorowe on soght, syne Ã¾ai haue seruid so. Ãare mys may neuer be amendid sen Ã¾ai a-sent me to forsake, For all Ã¾ere force non sall Ã¾ame fende for to be fendys foule & blake. And Ã¾o Ã¾at lykys with me to lende, and trewly tent to me will take, Sall wonne in welth withoutyn ende, and all-way wynly with me wake. Ãai salle haue for Ã¾are sele solace Ã¾at neuer sall sclake. Ãis warke me thynkys full wele, and more now will I make. Syne Ã¾at Ã¾is world es ordand euyn, furth well I publysch my powere, Noght by my strenkyth but by my steuyn, a firmament I byd apere; Emange Ã¾e waterris lyght so leuyn, Ã¾ere cursis lely for to lere, And Ã¾at same sall be namyd hewuyn, with planitys and with clowdis clere. Ãe water I will be set to flowe bothe fare and nere, And Ã¾an Ã¾e firmament, in mydis to set Ã¾ame sere; Ãe firmament sal nough[t] moue, but be a mene, Ã¾us will I mene, Ouir all Ã¾e worlde to halde and houe, And be you tow wateris be-twyne. Vndir Ã¾e heuyn, and als a-boue, Ã¾e wateris serly sall be sene, And so I wille my post proue, by creaturis of kyndis clene. Ãis warke is to my pay righit well, withoutyn wyne, Ãus sese Ã¾e secunde day of my doyngys bydene. Moo sutyll werkys asse-say I sall, for to be set in seruice sere; Alle ye wateris grete and smalle Ã¾at vndir heuyne er ordande here, Gose to-gedir and holde yow all, and be a flode festynde in fere, So Ã¾at the erthe, bothe downe and dale, in drynesch playnly may a-pere; Ãe drynes âlandeâ sall be namyd, bothe ferre and nere, And Ã¾en I name Ã¾e âse,â geddryng of wateris clere. Ãe erthe sall fostyr and furthe bryng, buxsumly as I wyle byde, Erbys and also othyr thyng, well for to wax and worthe to wede; Treys also Ã¾ar-on sall spryng, with braunchis and with bowis on-brede, With flouris fayr on heght to hyng, and fruth also to fylle and fede. And Ã¾ane I will Ã¾at Ã¾ay of Ã¾em selfe haue Ã¾e sede, And mater Ã¾at Ã¾ay may be lastande furth in lede. And all Ã¾er materis es in mynde, for to be made of mekyl might, And to be kest in dyueris kynde so for to bere sere burgvns bright. And when Ã¾er frutys is fully fynde, and fayrest semande vnto syght, Ãane Ã¾e wedris wete and wynde oway I will it wende full wyght, And of Ã¾ere sede full sone, new rotys sall ryse vp right. Ãe third day Ã¾us is done, Ã¾ire dedis er dewly dyght. Now sene Ã¾e erthe Ã¾us ordand es, mesurid and made by myn assent, Grathely for to growe with gres, and wedis Ã¾at sone away bese went, Of my gudnes now will I ges, so Ã¾at my werkis no harmes hent, Two lyghtis, one more and one lesse, to be fest in Ã¾e firmament; The more light to [the] day fully suthely sall be sent, Ãe lesse lyght all-way to Ã¾e nyght sall take entent. Ãir figuris fayre Ã¾at further sun Ã¾us on sere sydys serue Ã¾ai sall, The more lyght sall be namid Ã¾e son, dymnes to wast be downe and be dale; Erbis and treys Ã¾at er by-gune, all sall he gouerne, gret and smale, With cald yf Ã¾ai be closid or bun, thurgh hete of Ã¾e sun Ã¾ai sal be hale. Als ye I haue honours in alkyn welth to wale, So sall my creaturis euir byde withoutyn bale. Ãe son and Ã¾e mone on fayre manere, now grathly gange in ?our degre, Als ye haue tane ?oure curses clere to serue furth loke ye be fre, For ye sall set Ã¾e sesons sere, kyndely to knowe in ilke cuntre, Day fro day, and yere fro yere, by sertayne signes suthly to se. Ãe heuyn sall be ouer hyld with sternys to stand plente. Ãe furthe day his fulfillid; Ã¾is werke well lykys me. Now sen Ã¾ir werkis er wroght with wyne, and fundyn furth be firth and fell, Ãe see now will I set within whallis whikly for to dewell; And othir fysch to flet with fyne, sum with skale and sum with skell, Of diueris materis more and myn, in sere maner to make and mell; Sum sall be milde and meke, and sum both fers and fell, Ãis world Ã¾us will I eke, syn I am witt of well. Also vp in Ã¾e ayre on hyght I byd now Ã¾at Ã¾ore be ordande, For to be foulis fayre and bright, dewly in Ã¾are degre dwelland, With fedrys fayre to frast Ã¾er flight fro stede to stede where Ã¾ai will stande, And also leythly for to lyght whore so Ã¾ame lykis in ilke a londe. Ãane fysch and foulis sere, kyndely I ?ow commande, To meng on ?oure mannere, both be se and sande. Ãis materis more ?itt will I mende, so for to fulfill my for-thoght, With diueris bestis in lande to lende to brede & be with bale furth brught: And with bestis I wille be blende serpentis to be sene vn-soght, And wormis vp-on Ã¾aire wombis sall wende, to wo in erth and worth to noght. And so it sall be kende how all Ã¾at eme is oght, Begynnyng mydes and ende I with my worde hase wrothe. For als I byde bus all thyng be, and dewly done als I will dresse; Now bestys ar sett in sere degre on molde to moue, both more & lesse. Ãane foulis in ayre, and fische in see, and bestis on erthe of bone and flesch, I byde ?e wax furth fayre plente, and grathly growes, als I ?ow gesse. So multeply ?e sall ay furth in fayre processe, My blyssyng haue ?e all; the fift day endyd es.
